<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SOCIAL MEDIA
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/04/facebook-apps-out-for-six-hours?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Facebook Takes a Half Day<br>
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/04/facebook-apps-out-for-six-hours?utm_source=morning_brew&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_campaign=mb" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Twitter's tweet " hello literally everyone"" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/0ee178db15b7b774d3873af12e35b5532dae43ca-1180x412.png?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Twitter</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Facebook, Instagram, and WhatsApp all suffered widespread <a href="https://link.morningbrew.com/click/25234013.0/aHR0cHM6Ly9hcG5ld3MuY29tL2FydGljbGUvZmFjZWJvb2std2hhdHNhcHAtaW5zdGFncmFtLW91dGFnZS04YjlkMzg2MmVkOTU3MDI5ZTU0NTE4MmE1OTVmZGNlMT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5f10d6a212c71038741b0759B2148726b?utm_source=morning_brew&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_campaign=mb" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">global outages</a> yesterday, which meant the only places to share niche hot takes were Twitter or a Michael’s craft store comment section. Messenger, Oculus VR, and Facebook’s internal communications tools also stopped working.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">It appears to be the company’s largest outage in history based on the number of users affected.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Here’s what we know</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Facebook-owned platforms disappeared from the internet around 11:40am ET and stayed that way until about 6pm ET, when the apps started to work again. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Late last night, the company <a href="https://engineering.fb.com/2021/10/04/networking-traffic/outage/?utm_source=morning_brew&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_campaign=mb" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">confirmed</a> theories that the outage was caused during a routine update to the company’s Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) records. In other words, someone at Facebook “took away the map telling the world’s computers how to find its various online properties,” cybersecurity reporter Brian Krebs <a href="https://krebsonsecurity.com/2021/10/what-happened-to-facebook-instagram-whatsapp/?utm_source=morning_brew&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_campaign=mb" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">wrote</a>.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Plenty of jokes were made. </strong>Because Facebook’s internal communications systems were disrupted, some FB employees described it as a “snow day.” And Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey joined many users in <a href="https://www.theverge.com/tldr/2021/10/4/22709235/twitter-jack-dorsey-dunk-facebook-outage-dns?utm_source=morning_brew&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_campaign=mb" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">dunking on Zuck</a>.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">But a Facebook outage isn’t all fun & memes.</strong> More than 3.5 billion people use FB’s platforms to conduct business and communicate with friends and family. “Sorry for the disruption today—I know how much you rely on our services to stay connected with the people you care about,” Mark Zuckerberg wrote when the sites had been restored.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">It was already an intense day at the office</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">On Sunday night, former Facebook product manager Frances Haugen, who leaked tens of thousands of pages of documents to the WSJ and the SEC, <a href="https://link.morningbrew.com/click/25234013.0/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubW9ybmluZ2JyZXcuY29tL2RhaWx5L3N0b3JpZXMvMjAyMS8xMC8wMy9mYWNlYm9vay13aGlzdGxlYmxvd2VyLXJldmVhbHMtaGVyc2VsZi10by1iZS1mb3JtZXItcHJvZHVjdC1tYW5hZ2VyLWZyYW5jZXMtaGF1Z2VuP3V0bV9zb3VyY2U9bW9ybmluZ19icmV3/5f10d6a212c71038741b0759B3df7b3d1?utm_source=morning_brew&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_campaign=mb" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">went on <em>60 Minutes</em></a><em> </em>to argue that the company was prioritizing engagement over user safety.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Facebook shares, which had already been sliding after Haugen revealed herself to be the whistleblower, fell more than 5% yesterday. It was the stock’s worst day all year.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>this week will only get rockier for Facebook as Haugen is set to testify today before a Senate subcommittee about Facebook and Instagram. —<em>MM</em></p>
</div>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
RETAIL
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/04/psa-order-your-holiday-presents-now?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
PSA: Order Your Holiday Presents Now
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/04/psa-order-your-holiday-presents-now?utm_source=morning_brew&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_campaign=mb" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Home Alone gif" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/df2daf5a6b622aee6b47563778c6a0a715ae54d4-480x260.gif?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">This holiday season, the role of Ebenezer Scrooge will be played by the broken global supply chain.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Exhibit A: </strong>Amazon <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2021/10/04/amazon-begins-early-black-friday-deals-to-jumpstart-holiday-shopping.html?utm_source=morning_brew&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_campaign=mb" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">rolled out</a> “Black Friday-worthy” deals yesterday, exactly *checks notes* 53 days before <em>actual </em>Black Friday. The company said customers should expect “deep discounts across every category,” and also rolled out a tool that allows Prime members to send gifts to people without putting in an address.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px"><li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Target is also kicking off its holiday promo next week to attract customers who want to knock out their shopping list before the leaves lose their chlorophyll.</span></li></ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>Black Friday creep has been happening for a while, but this year’s shopping season is set to be the longest ever, as retailers give themselves breathing room to accommodate delivery delays caused by <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/features/2021-10-04/out-of-stock-shortages-for-christmas-shopping-put-retailers-at-risk?utm_source=morning_brew&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_campaign=mb" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">supply chain bottlenecks</a>.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Factories in Asia have been closed due to Covid lockdowns, shipping containers are harder to find than a heat lamp, and companies are struggling to hire workers to staff ports and drive trucks. “I’ve been doing this for 43 years and never seen it this bad,” the CEO of toymaker MGA Entertainment told Bloomberg.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">+ For more retail news: </strong>Of course there’s a Brew newsletter for that. You can sign up for Retail Brew <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/retail/?utm_source=morning_brew&utm_medium=inline&utm_campaign=link&email={email}" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">right here</a>. —<em>NF</em></p>
</div>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
MEDIA
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/04/ozy-media-ceo-carlos-watson-says-the-company-will-return-after-shutting-down?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Ozy Fakes Its Own Death
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/04/ozy-media-ceo-carlos-watson-says-the-company-will-return-after-shutting-down?utm_source=morning_brew&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_campaign=mb" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Carlos Watson on the Today Show" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/a761bdab86ae37666aacca370c3daed4b62e7c19-1024x512.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>NBC</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Ozy Media CEO Carlos Watson <a href="https://www.today.com/video/ozy-media-ceo-carlos-watson-speaks-out-exclusively-on-today-122672197663?utm_source=morning_brew&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_campaign=mb" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">declared</a> on the <em>Today</em> show yesterday that his media company was going to “open for business.” It’s a curious thing to say considering Ozy announced on Friday that it was shutting down.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">A quick timeline: </strong>In late September, an NYT <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/09/26/business/media/ozy-media-goldman-sachs.html?utm_source=morning_brew&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_campaign=mb" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">investigation</a> revealed that Ozy’s business practices were about as legit as whatever is in a Hot Pocket. Ozy is accused of inflating its audience numbers and acknowledged that COO Samir Rao impersonated a YouTube exec on a pitch to a potential investor. After growing backlash, the company fired most of its staff and said it was closing its doors last week.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But Watson did some deep thinking over the weekend and, after conversations with investors, advertisers, and former employees, believes a revival is possible. He called it Ozy’s “<a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/ozy-media-says-it-plans-to-relaunch-in-about-face-11633370757?mod=pls_whats_news_us_business_f" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Lazarus moment</a>” in a nod to a follower of Jesus who was raised from the dead.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>despite having only two board members and virtually no staff, Watson said Ozy will release at least one new TV show by early next month, a <a href="https://www.axios.com/carlos-watson-ozy-interview-relaunch-board-members-6467e469-080e-446f-b0b0-6b15699294f3.html?utm_source=morning_brew&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_campaign=mb" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">new podcast</a> by EOQ, and newsletters by the end of the week. Siri, define chutzpah. —<em>MM</em></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">(Disclosure: Last year Morning Brew engaged in a small cross-promotion effort with Ozy.)</p>
</div>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SPONSORED BY JOBSOHIO
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="#" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
You’re Not in Kansas Anymore
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://ad.doubleclick.net/ddm/trackclk/N9515.3407870MORNINGBREW0/B26024051.311666064;dc_trk_aid=504799923;dc_trk_cid=138232885;dc_lat=;dc_rdid=;tag_for_child_directed_treatment=;tfua=;ltd=" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="JobsOhio" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://media2.morningbrew.com/uploads/placement/images/3921/1632431006-JO_Morningbrew_1500x850_Cleveland.jpg">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em></em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><a href="https://ad.doubleclick.net/ddm/trackclk/N9515.3407870MORNINGBREW0/B26024051.311666064;dc_trk_aid=504799923;dc_trk_cid=138232885;dc_lat=;dc_rdid=;tag_for_child_directed_treatment=;tfua=;ltd=" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">You’re in Ohio</a>. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">What are you doing in Ohio? Odds are you aren’t here for the state flower, although the carnations certainly are lovely. Nor are you here because you have a thing for cardinals, Ohio’s official state bird.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">You moved to Ohio because you decided to go where business is booming, and you know it’s a state with low taxes and top-rated affordability. In fact, <strong style="color:#000">Ohio was ranked the No. 1 Most Affordable State in 2020 by US News Rankings</strong>.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Not to mention that the biggest names in tech can’t resist the charms of Ohio, like its generous statewide programs and burgeoning STEM community. <a href="https://ad.doubleclick.net/ddm/trackclk/N9515.3407870MORNINGBREW0/B26024051.311666064;dc_trk_aid=504799923;dc_trk_cid=138232885;dc_lat=;dc_rdid=;tag_for_child_directed_treatment=;tfua=;ltd=" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Facebook, Google, IBM, Amazon Web Services, and other tech leaders</a> recognize the benefits of doing business in the Buckeye State.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Whether you specialize in state-of-the-art software, artificial intelligence, cybersecurity, or data science, <strong style="color:#000">JobsOhio can help you grow your business at a fraction of the cost</strong>.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><a href="https://ad.doubleclick.net/ddm/trackclk/N9515.3407870MORNINGBREW0/B26024051.311666064;dc_trk_aid=504799923;dc_trk_cid=138232885;dc_lat=;dc_rdid=;tag_for_child_directed_treatment=;tfua=;ltd=" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Learn more today</a>.</p>

<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
GRAB BAG
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/04/key-performance-indicators-october-5?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Key Performance Indicators
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">

<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Stat: </strong>98% of members of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees (IATSE) voted to <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2021/10/04/iatse-strike-hollywood-union-workers-approve-measure-to-call-a-strike.html?utm_source=morning_brew&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_campaign=mb" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">authorize</a> a strike, which could halt TV and film production around the country. It’s the first time in the union’s 128-year history that members have greenlit a nationwide strike. We wrote about what the workers are demanding <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/01/historic-strike-could-soon-shut-down-hollywood?utm_source=morning_brew&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_campaign=mb" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">here</a>.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Quote: </strong>“Your work is going to fill a large part of your life, and the only way to be truly satisfied is to do what you believe is great work. And the only way to do great work is to love what you do. If you haven’t found it yet, keep looking. Don’t settle.”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Apple cofounder Steve Jobs died 10 years ago today. He was very much in the “follow your passion” camp.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Read: </strong>The act of smelling. <!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SCIENCE
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/04/hot-pepper-research-just-won-the-nobel-prize?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Hot Pepper Research Just Won the Nobel Prize
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/04/hot-pepper-research-just-won-the-nobel-prize?utm_source=morning_brew&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_campaign=mb" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="A pile of hot peppers." style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/b9d53d4d57ead1a6718785be2de5b541a1d8d554-2880x1919.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em></em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine was awarded on Monday to a pair of scientists who, partly by working with hot peppers, made major discoveries about the human nervous system. Hear that, Buffalo Wild Wings? 2022’s your year.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Scientists David Julius and Ardem Patapoutian were awarded the prize for their work identifying how exactly humans sense heat, cold, and touch—specifically, how these sensations initiate signals in the nervous system.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Give it up for chili peppers and pipettes:</strong></p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Through experiments </span><span><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/10/04/health/nobel-prize-medicine-physiology-temperature-touch.html?utm_source=morning_brew&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_campaign=mb" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">using capsaicin</a></span><span> (the chemical that makes peppers hot), Dr. Julius identified a specific sensor in our nerves that signals pain and heat sensations.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>By poking a cell line </span><span><a href="https://www.science.org/content/article/hot-and-cool-research-wins-nobel-prize-physiology-or-medicine?utm_source=morning_brew&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_campaign=mb" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">with a pipette</a></span><span> and silencing touch receptor genes, Dr. Patapoutian discovered sensors that allow us to feel the sensation of “touch” and “pressure.”</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">So why does it matter?</strong> According to <a href="https://www.nobelprize.org/prizes/medicine/2021/press-release/?utm_source=morning_brew&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_campaign=mb" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">the Nobel committee</a>, the scientists identified “critical missing links” in our understanding of how our bodies respond to the environment, and their research has led to a “rapid increase” in our understanding of our nervous system. Their discoveries could lead to the development of non-opioid painkillers and treatments for “a wide range of disease conditions, including chronic pain.” —<em>MK</em></p>
</div>

</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">

href=\"https://link.morningbrew.com/click/25234013.0/aHR0cHM6Ly9hcG5ld3MuY29tL2FydGljbGUvZmFjZWJvb2std2hhdHNhcHAtaW5zdGFncmFtLW91dGFnZS04YjlkMzg2MmVkOTU3MDI5ZTU0NTE4MmE1OTVmZGNlMT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5f10d6a212c71038741b0759B2148726b?utm_source=morning_brew\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_campaign=mb\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eglobal outages\u003c/a\u003e yesterday, which meant the only places to share niche hot takes were Twitter or a Michael’s craft store comment section. Messenger, Oculus VR, and Facebook’s internal communications tools also stopped working.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIt appears to be the company’s largest outage in history based on the number of users affected.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eHere’s what we know\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eFacebook-owned platforms disappeared from the internet around 11:40am ET and stayed that way until about 6pm ET, when the apps started to work again. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eLate last night, the company \u003ca href=\"https://engineering.fb.com/2021/10/04/networking-traffic/outage/?utm_source=morning_brew\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_campaign=mb\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003econfirmed\u003c/a\u003e theories that the outage was caused during a routine update to the company’s Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) records. In other words, someone at Facebook “took away the map telling the world’s computers how to find its various online properties,” cybersecurity reporter Brian Krebs \u003ca href=\"https://krebsonsecurity.com/2021/10/what-happened-to-facebook-instagram-whatsapp/?utm_source=morning_brew\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_campaign=mb\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewrote\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003ePlenty of jokes were made. \u003c/strong\u003eBecause Facebook’s internal communications systems were disrupted, some FB employees described it as a “snow day.” And Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey joined many users in \u003ca href=\"https://www.theverge.com/tldr/2021/10/4/22709235/twitter-jack-dorsey-dunk-facebook-outage-dns?utm_source=morning_brew\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_campaign=mb\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edunking on Zuck\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBut a Facebook outage isn’t all fun \u0026 memes.\u003c/strong\u003e More than 3.5 billion people use FB’s platforms to conduct business and communicate with friends and family. “Sorry for the disruption today—I know how much you rely on our services to stay connected with the people you care about,” Mark Zuckerberg wrote when the sites had been restored.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eIt was already an intense day at the office\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eOn Sunday night, former Facebook product manager Frances Haugen, who leaked tens of thousands of pages of documents to the WSJ and the SEC, \u003ca href=\"https://link.morningbrew.com/click/25234013.0/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubW9ybmluZ2JyZXcuY29tL2RhaWx5L3N0b3JpZXMvMjAyMS8xMC8wMy9mYWNlYm9vay13aGlzdGxlYmxvd2VyLXJldmVhbHMtaGVyc2VsZi10by1iZS1mb3JtZXItcHJvZHVjdC1tYW5hZ2VyLWZyYW5jZXMtaGF1Z2VuP3V0bV9zb3VyY2U9bW9ybmluZ19icmV3/5f10d6a212c71038741b0759B3df7b3d1?utm_source=morning_brew\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_campaign=mb\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewent on \u003cem\u003e60 Minutes\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e \u003c/em\u003eto argue that the company was prioritizing engagement over user safety.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eFacebook shares, which had already been sliding after Haugen revealed herself to be the whistleblower, fell more than 5% yesterday. It was the stock’s worst day all year.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003ethis week will only get rockier for Facebook as Haugen is set to testify today before a Senate subcommittee about Facebook and Instagram. width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThis holiday season, the role of Ebenezer Scrooge will be played by the broken global supply chain.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eExhibit A: \u003c/strong\u003eAmazon \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2021/10/04/amazon-begins-early-black-friday-deals-to-jumpstart-holiday-shopping.html?utm_source=morning_brew\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_campaign=mb\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003erolled out\u003c/a\u003e “Black Friday-worthy” deals yesterday, exactly *checks notes* 53 days before \u003cem\u003eactual \u003c/em\u003eBlack Friday. The company said customers should expect “deep discounts across every category,” and also rolled out a tool that allows Prime members to send gifts to people without putting in an address.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eTarget is also kicking off its holiday promo next week to attract customers who want to knock out their shopping list before the leaves lose their chlorophyll.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eBlack Friday creep has been happening for a while, but this year’s shopping season is set to be the longest ever, as retailers give themselves breathing room to accommodate delivery delays caused by \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/features/2021-10-04/out-of-stock-shortages-for-christmas-shopping-put-retailers-at-risk?utm_source=morning_brew\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_campaign=mb\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esupply chain bottlenecks\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eFactories in Asia have been closed due to Covid lockdowns, shipping containers are harder to find than a heat lamp, and companies are struggling to hire workers to staff ports and drive trucks. “I’ve been doing this for 43 years and never seen it this bad,” the CEO of toymaker MGA Entertainment told Bloomberg.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e+ For more retail news: \u003c/strong\u003eOf course there’s a Brew newsletter for that. target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edeclared\u003c/a\u003e on the \u003cem\u003eToday\u003c/em\u003e show yesterday that his media company was going to “open for business.” It’s a curious thing to say considering Ozy announced on Friday that it was shutting down.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eA quick timeline: \u003c/strong\u003eIn late September, an NYT \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2021/09/26/business/media/ozy-media-goldman-sachs.html?utm_source=morning_brew\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_campaign=mb\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003einvestigation\u003c/a\u003e revealed that Ozy’s business practices were about as legit as whatever is in a Hot Pocket. Ozy is accused of inflating its audience numbers and acknowledged that COO Samir Rao impersonated a YouTube exec on a pitch to a potential investor. After growing backlash, the company fired most of its staff and said it was closing its doors last week.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut Watson did some deep thinking over the weekend and, after conversations with investors, advertisers, and former employees, believes a revival is possible. He called it Ozy’s “\u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/ozy-media-says-it-plans-to-relaunch-in-about-face-11633370757?mod=pls_whats_news_us_business_f\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eLazarus moment\u003c/a\u003e” in a nod to a follower of Jesus who was raised from the dead.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003edespite having only two board members and virtually no staff, Watson said Ozy will release at least one new TV show by early next month, a \u003ca href=\"https://www.axios.com/carlos-watson-ozy-interview-relaunch-board-members-6467e469-080e-446f-b0b0-6b15699294f3.html?utm_source=morning_brew\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_campaign=mb\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003enew podcast\u003c/a\u003e by EOQ, and newsletters by the end of the week. Siri, define chutzpah. —\u003cem\u003eMM\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e(Disclosure: Last year Morning Brew engaged in a small cross-promotion effort with Ozy.)\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/04/hot-pepper-research-just-won-the-nobel-prize?utm_source=morning_brew\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_campaign=mb\" style=\"text-decoration:none;border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"A pile of hot peppers.\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/b9d53d4d57ead1a6718785be2de5b541a1d8d554-2880x1919.jpg?w=670\u0026q=70\u0026auto=format\"\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine was awarded on Monday to a pair of scientists who, partly by working with hot peppers, made major discoveries about the human nervous system. Hear that, Buffalo Wild Wings? 2022’s your year.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eScientists David Julius and Ardem Patapoutian were awarded the prize for their work identifying how exactly humans sense heat, cold, and touch—specifically, how these sensations initiate signals in the nervous system.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eGive it up for chili peppers and pipettes:\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eThrough experiments \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2021/10/04/health/nobel-prize-medicine-physiology-temperature-touch.html?utm_source=morning_brew\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_campaign=mb\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eusing capsaicin\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e (the chemical that makes peppers hot), Dr. Julius identified a specific sensor in our nerves that signals pain and heat sensations.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eBy poking a cell line \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.science.org/content/article/hot-and-cool-research-wins-nobel-prize-physiology-or-medicine?utm_source=morning_brew\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_campaign=mb\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewith a pipette\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e and silencing touch receptor genes, Dr. Patapoutian discovered sensors that allow us to feel the sensation of “touch” and “pressure.”\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eSo why does it matter?\u003c/strong\u003e According to \u003ca href=\"https://www.nobelprize.org/prizes/medicine/2021/press-release/?utm_source=morning_brew\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_campaign=mb\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ethe Nobel committee\u003c/a\u003e, the scientists identified “critical missing links” in our understanding of how our bodies respond to the environment, and their research has led to a “rapid increase” in our understanding of our nervous system. Their discoveries could lead to the development of non-opioid painkillers and treatments for “a wide range of disease conditions, including chronic pain.”
